Israel hits Sanaa airport and other Houthi targets across Yemen - Euronews
summary:
Israel hits Sanaa airport and other Houthi targets across Yemen

Publication date: Not specified, Source: Not specified

The Israeli army conducted airstrikes against Houthi targets in Yemen, including major facilities in the capital Sanaa, as a response to escalating missile and drone attacks from the Iran-backed group.

  • The airstrikes targeted Sanaa International Airport, two major power plants, and ports on Yemen's western coast.
  • Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and defence officials approved the military action.
  • The missile launched from Yemen activated air raid sirens in central Israel but was intercepted before causing damage.
  • Prior incidents included a missile hitting a playground in Tel Aviv, injuring 16 people.
  • Israel's foreign minister has called for a UN Security Council meeting to address Houthi aggression and Iranian support.
“These infrastructures were used by the Houthi terror regime to transfer Iranian weapons to the region and for the entry of senior Iranian officials,” IDF statement.

These airstrikes signify a significant escalation in the regional conflict and a direct response to Houthi provocations against Israel.
newTitle: Israel Launches Airstrikes on Houthi Targets in Yemen

title: Big danger for Pakistan as Taliban declares war against Islamabad as revenge against deadly airstrikes, sends - India.com
summary:
Taliban Threatens Pakistan Following Airstrikes: 15,000 Fighters Mobilized

Publication Date: December 26, 2024 | Source: India.com

Pakistan faces escalating tensions as the Taliban retaliates against airstrikes aimed at the Tehreek-i-Taliban Pakistan (TTP). This conflict could significantly impact both nations' stability.

  • The Taliban has mobilized 15,000 fighters towards Pakistan's borders in response to recent airstrikes.
  • Pakistan's airstrikes were targeted at TTP camps in Afghanistan, asserting the need to protect its citizens.
  • Several recent terrorist attacks have led to civilian casualties in Pakistan, heightening the urgency of the situation.
  • Afghanistan has expressed strong protest to Pakistan over these military actions.
“Taliban is in no mood to spare Pakistan, ready to bite the hands of those that fed and nourished them.”

This situation underscores the volatile nature of regional geopolitics and the potential for further conflict if diplomatic solutions are not sought.
newTitle: Taliban Threatens Pakistan Following Airstrikes: 15,000 Fighters Mobilized

title: Govt imposes restrictions on import of low ash metallurgical coke for 6 months | Company Business News - Mint
summary:
Govt imposes restrictions on import of low ash metallurgical coke for 6 months

Date: December 26, 2023 Source: PTI

The government has announced import restrictions on low ash metallurgical coke for six months, effective from January 1, 2025, to June 30, 2025. This includes quantitative restrictions from various countries.

  • Import restrictions apply to low ash metallurgical coke.
  • Quantitative restrictions are set for imports from countries such as Australia, China, Colombia, and others.
  • High ash content coke (above 18%) is not subject to these restrictions.
  • The imports will require authorisation from the Directorate General of Foreign Trade (DGFT).
  • Quarterly monitoring will ensure that imports do not exceed specified quotas.
"The country-wise QR will be effective from January 2025 and will cease automatically on June 30, next year."

This measure aims to regulate the import of low ash metallurgical coke and ensure compliance with trade remedies.
newTitle: Govt imposes restrictions on import of low ash metallurgical coke for 6 months

Exhilaration and speculation are on the rise following the maiden flights of two advanced sixth-generation fighter jets from China, stirring extensive discussion across social media.

  • Experts are split, with some suggesting the aircraft might represent a significant advancement in military aviation technology.

“This and GCAP may demand some urgent re-thinking in regards to NGAD,” said Dr. Malcolm Davis, emphasizing the rapid advancements in China's military aviation.

China's latest developments in fighter technology pose challenges for the US and allies, potentially accelerating their own programs.

India Sends First Shipment of Rice to Bangladesh Amid Political Tensions

Date: December 26, 2024

Source: India.com

The interim government of Bangladesh is set to receive its first consignment of rice imported from India, representing a significant development amid shifting political alliances.

  • The ship ‘MV Tanais Dream’ will arrive at Chauddagram Port carrying 24,690 metric tonnes of parboiled rice.
  • This marks the first instance of rice imports from India under an open trade agreement.
  • The event follows a recent warming of relations, with ships arriving from Karachi to Bangladesh.
“We will collect the sample of rice after conducting a physical examination and the process of unloading will commence.” - Bangladesh food ministry official

This rice shipment signals a hopeful step towards improving diplomatic relations between India and Bangladesh, which has recently seen fluctuating ties.

title: Trump tells death row inmates granted clemency by Biden to ‘go to hell’ in scathing Christmas Day message - Hindustan Times
summary:
Trump tells death row inmates granted clemency by Biden to ‘go to hell’ in scathing Christmas Day message

Date: Dec 26, 2024 | Source: Hindustan Times

In a recent Christmas Day statement, Donald Trump sharply criticized Joe Biden's decision to commute the sentences of 37 federal death row inmates. Trump directed harsh remarks at these inmates and the Democrats, expressing his disdain and opposition to the clemency granted.

  • Trump told death row inmates to “go to hell” in response to Biden's clemency.
  • The statement came after Biden commuted the sentences of 37 out of 40 death row inmates, many of whom include violent criminals.
  • Trump referred to Biden derogatorily as “sleepy Joe” and criticized the Democrats as “radical left lunatics.”
  • He vowed to “make America great again” in the upcoming weeks.
  • Trump’s comments were aimed at discrediting the Democrats' approach to justice and politics.
“To the 37 most violent criminals, who killed, raped, and plundered… I refuse to wish a Merry Christmas to those lucky 'souls' but, instead, will say, GO TO HELL!” - Donald Trump

This statement highlights Trump's controversial rhetoric and the political tensions surrounding criminal justice in the United States as he prepares to take office.
newTitle: Trump's Scathing Message to Death Row Inmates Granted Clemency by Biden

Report: Mossad chief believes Israel should target Iran to get at Houthis; PM disagrees - The Times of Israel
summary:
Mossad Chief Advocates Targeting Iran to Counter Houthi Threats; Netanyahu Disagrees

Date: December 25, 2024

Source: The Times of Israel

In a recent development, Mossad chief David Barnea has urged Israeli leadership to focus on attacking Iran to mitigate threats from the Houthi rebels, contrasting with the views of PM Netanyahu and Defense Minister Katz who prefer direct strikes against the Houthis.

  • Barnea believes targeting Iran is more effective as it funds and arms the Houthis.
  • Israeli officials indicated plans for increased military activity against the Houthis in response to recent missile and drone attacks.
  • PM Netanyahu maintains that the situation with Iran must be addressed separately in due time.
  • Air Force Chief Tomer Bar affirmed the commitment to intensify attacks on Houthi targets.
  • Former Defense Minister Yoav Gallant supports collaboration with the US against both the Houthis and Iran.
  • The article details ongoing Houthi assaults, including missile strikes that have resulted in injuries in Israel.
“We need to go head-on against Iran,” Barnea stated, highlighting the urgency of the situation.

The ongoing conflict with the Houthis reflects broader regional tensions, as missile and drone assaults from Yemen have become increasingly common.

As the Israeli military contemplates its strategy amidst escalating tensions, the coordination with US forces is expected to play a crucial role in shaping future actions against both the Houthis and Iran.
newTitle: Mossad Chief Advocates Targeting Iran to Counter Houthi Threats; Netanyahu Disagrees

title: Five Gaza journalists killed in Israeli strike - BBC.com
summary:
Tragic Loss of Life: Five Palestinian Journalists Killed in Israeli Strike

Published on: 2023-11-15, Source: BBC News

Five journalists from a Palestinian TV channel, Quds Today, were killed in an Israeli airstrike in the central Gaza Strip. The journalists were in a vehicle parked outside a hospital where one of their colleagues' wife was about to give birth. The Israeli military claimed it targeted a vehicle with members of the Palestinian Islamic Jihad group inside, with measures taken to minimize civilian casualties.

  1. The incident occurred in the Nuseirat refugee camp.
  2. The BBC could not verify claims from both sides.
  3. Earlier, five people were killed, and 20 injured in Israeli strikes on Gaza City.
  4. Ceasefire talks have been delayed due to disagreements between Israel and Hamas.
  5. The conflict began in response to a Hamas-led attack on Israel last October, with over 45,000 Palestinians killed and nearly two million displaced.
Quds Today is affiliated with the Palestinian Islamic Jihad group.

The loss of these journalists has raised concerns about the safety of media personnel in the conflict zone.
newTitle: Tragic Loss of Life: Five Palestinian Journalists Killed in Israeli Strike

For Uganda man with 12 wives, 102 kids, 578 grandchildren, feeding clan is a challenge - Hindustan Times
summary:
For Uganda man with 12 wives, 102 kids, 578 grandchildren, feeding clan is a challenge

Publication Date: N/A Source: Hindustan Times

Musa Hasahya Kasera, a 70-year-old villager from Mukiza in eastern Uganda, is facing the immense challenge of providing for his extraordinary family — 12 wives, 102 children, and 578 grandchildren. His situation has garnered local admiration and concern.

  • Hasahya's family began with his first marriage at age 17 in 1972.
  • The size of his family has put immense pressure on resources and living conditions.
  • He struggles to provide enough food, often resorting to feeding his large family only once or twice a day.
  • Family meetings are held monthly to resolve conflicts among wives and children.
  • Despite hardships, local officials recognize his ability to maintain relative peace among his family.
  • His wives' living conditions have led to some discontent; two have left the household.
  • To prevent further expansion, Hasahya's wives are now using contraceptives.
“I have learned my lesson,” Hasahya said. “I do not expect more children. I can’t look after any more.”

In conclusion, while Hasahya's family continues to grow, the pressing challenges of food security and family dynamics highlight the struggle of managing such a large household.
newTitle: The Challenges of a Ugandan Man with 12 Wives and 102 Children

title: Another Ukraine In Making? Trump Threatens To Seize A Region That U.S. Gave Up 25 Years Ago; Can He Do It? - EurAsian Times
summary:
Trump's Controversial Call to Retake Panama Canal Sparks Outrage

Publication Date: Recent

Source: EurAsian Times

In a provocative statement, President-elect Donald Trump suggested retaking the Panama Canal, arguing that Panama charges the U.S. exorbitant fees for its use.

  • Trump's comments draw parallels to the annexation of Crimea by Russia.
  • Panama's president firmly rejected Trump's claims, asserting that the canal belongs to Panama.
  • Trump emphasizes the canal's importance for U.S. national security and commerce.
  • Environmental concerns, such as drought affecting the canal's operation, have led to increased fees, which have angered Trump.
Trump stated, "We’re being ripped off at the Panama Canal like we’re being ripped off everywhere else."

The potential for escalating tensions between the U.S. and Panama looms as Trump's remarks could threaten diplomatic relations.
newTitle: Trump's Controversial Call to Retake Panama Canal Sparks Outrage

title: Russian air defence or bird strike: What caused Azerbaijan Airlines flight to crash? - The Indian Express
summary:
Azerbaijan Airlines Flight Crash: Investigating the Causes

Date: December 25, 2024 Source: Wall Street Journal

A plane crash near Kazakhstan’s Aktau city has resulted in the deaths of 38 passengers on board and is suspected to have been caused by a Russian anti-aircraft system. Conflicting reports from authorities in Russia and Azerbaijan regarding the cause of the crash have emerged.

  • The Azerbaijan Airlines flight was attempting an emergency landing when it crashed.
  • Conflicting explanations from Azerbaijan and Russia include bad weather and a potential bird strike.
  • The independent security firm Osprey Flight Solutions cites a possible missile involvement based on flight data.
  • Preliminary investigations are ongoing, with the black box recovered for analysis.
“Perforations in the plane’s tail section suggest that the crash could have been a result of a possible missile attack or the work of air defenses.”

The international implications and ongoing investigations into this tragic incident underscore vital questions about air safety in the region.
newTitle: Azerbaijan Airlines Flight Crash: Investigating the Causes

title: Russian air defence or bird strike: What happened to the Azerbaijan Airlines flight that crashed in Kazakhastan? - The Indian Express
summary:
Russian air defence or bird strike: What caused Azerbaijan Airlines flight to crash?

Date: December 25, 2024
Source: Wall Street Journal

A plane crash near Kazakhstan’s Aktau city, which killed 38 passengers on board, was likely caused by a Russian anti-aircraft system, according to reports. Investigations reveal conflicting accounts from authorities.

  • The flight was en route from Baku to Grozny when it crashed.
  • Preliminary investigations suggest the aircraft may have been shot down, according to a UK aviation security firm.
  • Russian authorities propose a bird strike might have been the cause, though experts challenge this theory.
  • An Azerbaijani official indicated bad weather as a contributing factor.
  • Footage suggests a steep descent before the crash, with reports of drone activity in the vicinity at the time.
“Video of the wreckage and the circumstances around the airspace security environment in southwest Russia indicates the possibility the aircraft was hit by some form of antiaircraft fire.” – Matt Borie, Osprey Flight Solutions

The investigation continues, with all parties eager to clarify the cause of this tragic incident.
newTitle: Investigation into Azerbaijan Airlines Flight Crash Raises Concerns

Sanctioned Russian LNG Ship Fails Four-Month Quest for Buyer | Company Business News - Mint
summary:
Sanctioned Russian LNG Ship Fails Four-Month Quest for Buyer

Published on: N/A - Source: Live Mint

The Pioneer tanker, carrying a sanctioned cargo of Russian liquefied natural gas, has offloaded its shipment into storage in Kamchatka after failing to secure a buyer willing to ignore US sanctions following a four-month journey.

  • The tanker docked next to the Koryak floating storage unit on Thursday.
  • Despite efforts, Pioneer could not find a customer for its cargo from the Arctic LNG 2 facility.
  • All parties involved, including the ship and facility, are under US sanctions.
  • Dark fleet vessels have been used for past shipments but have not docked at foreign ports.
  • Production at Arctic LNG 2 was halted in October due to a lack of buyers and suitable vessels.
  • Russia is building ice-breaker vessels to support LNG exports.
“The lengthy journey underlines just how US restrictions are hampering Moscow’s plans to expand LNG exports threefold by 2030.”

The inability of the Pioneer to find a buyer highlights the significant challenges posed by US sanctions on Russian LNG exports and raises concerns about the future of the Arctic LNG 2 facility.
newTitle: Sanctioned Russian LNG Ship Fails Four-Month Quest for Buyer

title: 20 years after calamity, woman recalls son 'Tsunami's birth in snake-filled jungle - Hindustan Times
summary:
20 years after calamity, woman recalls son 'Tsunami's birth in snake-filled jungle

Date: Dec 26, 2024 09:51 AM IST
Source: Hindustan Times

Twenty years after the devastating Indian Ocean tsunami, Namita Roy recalls giving birth to her son, Tsunami, in a snake-infested jungle after her home was destroyed.

  • Namita Roy was pregnant during the tsunami on December 26, 2004, which destroyed her home in Hut Bay Island.
  • She and her family took shelter in a jungle, where she gave birth with the help of other women after her husband couldn’t find medical help.
  • Roy now lives in West Bengal with her two sons, reflecting on the challenges they faced after the disaster.
  • Her son Tsunami aspires to be an oceanographer, while her elder son works in a shipping company.
  • Officials noted that the disaster highlighted the need for an effective warning system, leading to the establishment of over 1,400 warning stations globally.
"My mother is everything to me. She is the strongest person I have ever seen." - Tsunami Roy

The story of Namita Roy illustrates resilience and the lasting impact of the tsunami on her family and community, emphasizing the importance of preparedness in the face of natural disasters.
newTitle: 20 Years After the Tsunami: A Survivor's Story of Resilience
